title: Riot, your ranked system is broken. PLEASE address this issue...
body:
The TL;DR opening (closing at the bottom): I shouldn't have to play against Plat 5-3 players as a Gold 4 just to get promoted to Gold 3 and have to do it even more just to get to Gold 2.

The actual: I am working on climbing elo, and for a long time now, I have been playing against players who are several tiers higher than me. This has been happening ever since the horrible placement system somehow put me in Silver 4...But, of course, I am a patient guy so I just decided to start climbing. Sure enough climb I did. And the games were very easy and actually I felt a bit bad because there I was way below where I actually SHOULD have been (for real this time) and just crushing all these silver games and ruining the time of 5 other people (enemy team) game after game. It felt like i was smurfing, and it wasn't enjoyable for me or anyone else...

So by the time i reach Silver 1, my MMR was substantially higher than my actual rank was showing, and I was going against Gold 2/3 players consistently. That's fine, gold is also a bit simple. But of course, last season, if you severely outmatched the tier you were in, then you would skip a tier or two, so I patiently figured that instead of going from Silver 1 to Gold 5, I would go to at least Gold 4 or something, since I was already playing against gold 3 people.

Alas, I beat my promo's and ended up in Gold 5.....alright then, that's fine. Let me just climb one more tier, I am sure it will make sense after I beat Gold 5, right?

Nope, get promoted to gold 4. By this time I am constantly against Gold 1 and Plat 5 players, on a team of other gold 1's. And then there I randomly am...a lowly Gold 4...who ends up carrying the game anyway.

So, by the time I am in my promo's I am going against Plat 5-3 players. At this time I figure the logic is SO absolutely broken that it would only put me in Gold 3, so I patiently get through promo's quite handily and get my promotion....to Gold 3....and now I get to climb through Gold 3 going against Plat players.

At this rate, before I even reach Platinum, I will be playing against Diamond enemies.

So can someone PLEASE explain to me why this ends up being logical? How is it that in order to get just to Platinum, I have to beat out ALL the platinum players in the world?

TL;DR closing: Basing your matchmaking on MMR and not the actual tier you're in makes it a completely broken, unbalanced system, and I shouldn't have to beat people 4 tiers higher than me just to get to 3 tiers lower than them.

The new ranking system has been phenomenally successful.  The big 3 accomplishments:

* Killed tactical dodging without an elo penalty
* Fixed the ladder anxiety problem, resulting in more players playing ranked more often
* Fixed the tier break problem, resulting in just barely gold/plat/diamond players not wanting to quit ranked to preserve season rewards.

> Bring back the old system where you just had a number. Screw this broken "Division+Promo series" bullsh** you have now.

I said it as soon as they came out with the new system: it's just a sneaky way to get more players to play Ranked.

When Riot released the new system, they justified it by saying "well look how many more people are playing Ranked now, they obviously enjoy the new system!" instead of realizing the obvious: they're forcing people to play more games to get to their actual rank.

On the other hand, it cuts down on people getting to a rank they don't deserve, so there's that.

But why then have two completely different ranking systems? Why use a hidden MMR to match players together, but have a shown ranking that does not reflect the players skill? Shouldn't the ranked tiers represent a players skill? 

This confuses me, because shouldn't a players skill be reflected in their rank? Shouldn't players of the same rank be pitted against other players of similar shown ranking? If you're telling us that a players rank is not indicative of their skills as a player, why not show a players MMR in-game to get a gauge on how well they are being matched up against?

> But why then have two completely different ranking systems? Why use a hidden MMR to match players together, but have a shown ranking that does not reflect the players skill? Shouldn't the ranked tiers represent a players skill? 

Your league position is a lagging indicator.  Over time it tracks your actual rating.  If you go on a win streak, your LP will be lower than your MMR.  If you go on a losing stream, the reverse happens.  It still represents skill; it just reacts more calmly to recent events.

As for why we have it, the single most important reason to me is that you can have an LP penalty for dodging.  This means that people can't tank their elo using the dodge penalty to go noob stomp and people still fear the dodge penalty enough to not dodge tactically.  The other big reason is to repair ladder anxiety, which caused people that are e.g. just barely in the gold elo range to stop playing ranked in season 2.
IMO if you're matching a gold 3 players with plat 1 players and they're still winning half the time there's something wrong with calling them gold 3.

The reason I bring it up is because I check each game and it's a consistent pattern that I am going against people multiple tiers higher than me. If I see an outlier, say, a Plat 4 randomly showing up in my gold 4 games, then I don't see that as cause for concern at all. The problem I have is when they are ALL Gold 1+. If what you're saying is true and there are that many people several tiers ahead of me who are the same MMR as me...why am I still not getting the skip-tier situation? Or we can look at it this way...if there are that many Gold 1 and Plat players who are at the same MMR as me, why aren't THEY in Gold 3? Doesn't that reveal a different flaw if not flawed on my end? There is certainly a problem here when there is that large of a variance between myself, my teammates, and my opponents, you can't deny that.

> if there are that many Gold 1 and Plat players who are at the same MMR as me, why aren't THEY in Gold 3? 

The system is extremely lenient about demotions from plat 5 to gold 1.  You have to drop all the way down to a gold 5 MMR before it'll demote you out of plat.  Thus, you'll see a bunch of plat 5 players as you climb up towards making it there yourself; these guys were probably once playing at a plat level but they slacked off after achieving their goal for the season and now they're mid-gold tier players.  The practical result of this is that you shouldn't trust P5 players in your gold games to be any good at all.  Don't fear them, there's a good chance you're better than them if they're in your game.

As for the gold 1s with gold 3 MMR, they can exist due to grace periods and loss streak mechanics, but they won't exist for long.  

One of the things that Riot does is match you into games with different average skill levels.  You might be matched into a game where your team is on average gold 2, and you're the weakest player.  Riot will also intentionally skew the matchmaking in some games, where you might be playing with or against a MMR disadvantage this game; if you win into the disadvantage, you get tons of LP.  Both of these practices are intended to get a better reading on your skill level faster than just matching up a pure "all gold 3s play together" sort of thing.

To the OP

The point you are missing from the red post is that while you may be matched against people in higher divisions / tiers from you; it is solely because your skill level is higher than average for your tier.

The purpose of MMR based matching systems like this is to eventually get a player to a level where he is winning around 50% of his games. (because at that point he will not be advancing or declining very much if he stay at the same skill level)

Keep in mind that most people will not be climbing the ladder, but staying in their current position or declining. (this is obvious when you look at the player distribution for the leagues, and how the number of people in each successive league goes down immensely)

So keeping these points in mind, when you are in gold 4 and are being matched against gold 1 or platinum 5 or whatever, it isnt because your mmr is at the average of those tiers. It is because the people you are playing against likely have a below average mmr for their tier. (and likely that your mmr is above average for your tier)

The system is not broken this is how it is supposed to work. In my experience with the exact same kind of system, (getting to the master league in starcraft 2) the best thing you can do it just not think about your league or mmr so much and just focus on improving your game knowledge and mechanics, and the ranking will take care of itself.

MMR = matchmaking rating, I don't think anyone needs to argue with that... Tier is just icing on the cake for you to try and get 1 tier higher but it's all about wether or not your mmr is high enough or not.
